description: From Middle English truant, truand, trewande, trowant (= Middle Dutch trouwant, trawant, truwant), from Old French truand, truant (“a vagabond, beggar, rogue", also "beggarly, roguish”), of Celtic origin, perhaps from Gaulish *trugan, or from Breton truan (“wretched”), from Proto-Celtic *térh₁-tro-m, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *terh₁-.
Cognate with Scottish Gaelic truaghan, Irish trogha (“destitute”), trogán, Breton truc (“beggar”), Welsh tru.

entries.meaning: Absent without permission, especially from school.
examples: He didn't graduate because he was chronically truant and didn't have enough attendances to meet the requirement.

entries.meaning: Wandering from business or duty; straying; loitering; idle, and shirking duty.
One who is absent without permission, especially from school.

verbs.description: truant (third-person singular simple present truants, present participle truanting, simple past and past participle truanted)

examples: the number of schoolchildren known to have truanted
By this means they lost their time and truanted on the fundamental grounds of saving knowledge.
